title: Erdős Problem #530: Maximum Sidon Subsets of Finite Sets
description: For a finite set A of size N, what is the maximum size ℓ(N) of a Sidon subset? Komlós–Sulyok–Szemerédi: N^{1/2} ≪ ℓ(N) ≤ (1+o(1))N^{1/2}. Conjectured: ℓ(N) ~ N^{1/2}. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Originally posed by Riddell (1969) and studied extensively by Erdős. A Sidon set (B₂-set) has all pairwise sums distinct. Erdős proved N^{1/3} ≪ ℓ(N), improved to N^{1/2} ≪ ℓ(N) by Komlós, Sulyok, and Szemerédi. The upper bound (1+o(1))N^{1/2} comes from {1,...,N}.
overview.problemStatement: For a finite set A ⊂ ℝ of size N, let ℓ(N) denote the maximum size of a Sidon subset. Determine the order of growth of ℓ(N). It is conjectured that ℓ(N) ~ N^{1/2}.
overview.proofStrategy: We define Sidon sets as Finsets with distinct pairwise sums, define the maximum Sidon subset size, state the known lower bounds (Erdős; Komlós–Sulyok–Szemerédi) and upper bound, formalize the main conjecture, and state the Alon–Erdős partition conjecture.
keyInsights: A Sidon set of size k produces k(k+1)/2 distinct pairwise sums, bounding k ≤ O(N^{1/2})
Komlós–Sulyok–Szemerédi's probabilistic argument gives the matching lower bound N^{1/2} ≪ ℓ(N)
The Alon–Erdős partition conjecture (at most ~N^{1/2} Sidon parts) is a dual formulation
The gap between lower and upper bounds is only in the leading constant

sections.title: Sidon Set Definition
sections.summary: Defines IsSidon for Finset ℤ (distinct pairwise sums) and proves the empty set and singletons are Sidon.

sections.title: Maximum Sidon Subset Size
sections.summary: Defines maxSidonSize A as the supremum of card over Sidon subsets of A.

sections.title: Known Bounds
sections.summary: States Erdős's N^{1/3} lower bound, the Komlós–Sulyok–Szemerédi N^{1/2} lower bound, and the trivial N^{1/2} upper bound.

sections.title: The Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Formalizes Erdős Problem 530: ℓ(N) is Θ(N^{1/2}), with matching upper and lower bounds.

sections.title: Sidon Set Partition Conjecture
sections.summary: Defines Sidon partitions and states the Alon–Erdős conjecture: any N-element set can be partitioned into O(N^{1/2}) Sidon sets.

sections.title: Connection to B₂-sets
sections.summary: States that Sidon sets of size k have exactly k(k+1)/2 distinct pairwise sums, connecting to the additive combinatorics literature.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 530 asks for the order of growth of the maximum Sidon subset size ℓ(N). The known bounds N^{1/2} ≪ ℓ(N) ≤ (1+o(1))N^{1/2} leave only the leading constant undetermined. The problem remains open.
conclusion.implications: Resolving the exact asymptotics of ℓ(N) would advance our understanding of additive structure in arbitrary finite sets and connect to the partition problem of Alon and Erdős.
openQuestions: Is ℓ(N) = (1+o(1))N^{1/2} for all finite sets of size N?
Can every set of N integers be partitioned into (1+o(1))N^{1/2} Sidon sets?
What is the behavior of ℓ(N) for structured sets (e.g., arithmetic progressions)?
